messages.content:
Objective: Write code for a large system design task.
Please note that the code should be fully functional. No placeholders.
Only use the functions you have been provided with.
Only use the `write_files` to output code.

You must act autonomously and you will receive no human input at any stage. You have to return as output the complete code for completing this task, and correctly incorporate it into the existing code base.
You always write out the whole file contents. You always indent code with tabs.
Please always view the files before writing to them, to make sure you are writing to the correct files.
When writing a test, make the filename start with the prefix 'test_'.

Provide the minimal code necessary to achieve the task conditioned on the existing generated code---including changing the existing generated code.

You cannot visualize any graphical output. You exist within a Actor Model machine, and when you list out steps, each step will be taken by a new separate sub-ChatGPT model. When you list out a sub-task steps, you can optionally specify the sub-task validation to check that it has been completed successfully.

You cannot use any databases as none are setup in the local environment, instead mock a database with an in memory dictionary to store data. No data saved to disk will persist between steps or write operations.
                               
If a test is failing the error could be the code, or the test is incorrect, so feel free to overwrite and change the tests when they are incorrect, to make all tests pass.

Use the functions provided. When calling functions only provide a RFC8259 compliant JSON request following this format without deviation.

app.py: if blocker not in DATABASE['users'] or blockee not in DATABASE['users']:
if blocker not in DATABASE['users'] or blockee not in DATABASE['users']:

steps: Step 1: Start by setting up the basic structure of the application. This includes creating the main application file (app.py) and setting up a Flask application. Also, create a mock database using an in-memory dictionary to store user data. The database should have tables for users, messages, groups, and statuses. Each table should be a dictionary where the key is the unique identifier for the record (e.g., user ID, message ID, etc.) and the value is another dictionary representing the record. Write tests to ensure that the basic structure of the application and the mock database are set up correctly.

Step 2: Implement user registration and authentication. This includes creating routes for sign up and forgotten password recovery. The sign up route should accept an email and password, create a new user in the database, and return a success message. The forgotten password recovery route should accept an email, generate a temporary password, update the user's password in the database, and return the temporary password. Write tests to ensure that the registration and authentication routes work as expected.

Step 3: Implement user profile management. This includes creating routes for setting profile pictures and status messages, and for updating privacy settings. The profile picture and status message routes should accept a user ID and the new picture or message, update the user's record in the database, and return a success message. The privacy settings route should accept a user ID and the new settings, update the user's record in the database, and return a success message. Write tests to ensure that the profile management routes work as expected.

Step 4: Implement contact management. This includes creating routes for blocking and unblocking contacts, and for creating, editing, and managing groups. The block and unblock routes should accept two user IDs (the blocker and the blockee), update the blocker's record in the database, and return a success message. The group routes should accept a group ID and the new group data, update the group's record in the database, and return a success message. Write tests to ensure that the contact management routes work as expected.

Step 5: Implement messaging. This includes creating routes for sending and receiving messages, for updating read receipts, and for sharing images. The send and receive routes should accept a message ID and the message data, create a new message in the database, and return a success message. The read receipt route should accept a message ID, update the message's record in the database, and return a success message. The image sharing route should accept a message ID and the image data, create a new message in the database, and return a success message. Write tests to ensure that the messaging routes work as expected.

Step 6: Implement group chats. This includes creating routes for creating groups, for adding and removing participants, and for managing admin roles and permissions. The create group route should accept a group ID and the group data, create a new group in the database, and return a success message. The add and remove participants routes should accept a group ID and a user ID, update the group's record in the database, and return a success message. The admin roles and permissions route should accept a group ID and the new roles and permissions, update the group's record in the database, and return a success message. Write tests to ensure that the group chat routes work as expected.

Step 7: Implement the status/story feature. This includes creating routes for posting statuses and for managing who can see the status. The post status route should accept a user ID and the status data, create a new status in the database, and return a success message. The status visibility route should accept a user ID and the new visibility settings, update the user's record in the database, and return a success message. Write tests to ensure that the status/story routes work as expected.

Step 8: Implement the web application. This includes creating a route for serving the web application, and creating the HTML, CSS, and JavaScript files for the web application. The web application should use AJAX to interact with the Flask routes. Write tests to ensure that the web application route works as expected, and manually test the web application in a browser.

Step 9: Implement connectivity and offline mode. This includes creating a route for updating the online/offline status of a user, and for queuing messages when the user is offline. The online/offline status route should accept a user ID and the new status, update the user's record in the database, and return a success message. The message queuing route should accept a message ID and the message data, create a new message in the database with a status of 'queued', and return a success message. Write tests to ensure that the connectivity and offline mode routes work as expected.

Step 10: Finally, perform a comprehensive testing of the entire application. This includes running all the tests written in the previous steps, and manually testing the application in a browser. Fix any bugs that are found, and repeat the testing until all tests pass and the application works as expected.
step: Step 5: Implement messaging. This includes creating routes for sending and receiving messages, for updating read receipts, and for sharing images. The send and receive routes should accept a message ID and the message data, create a new message in the database, and return a success message. The read receipt route should accept a message ID, update the message's record in the database, and return a success message. The image sharing route should accept a message ID and the image data, create a new message in the database, and return a success message. Write tests to ensure that the messaging routes work as expected.

Please note that the code should be fully functional. No placeholders.
Only use the functions you have been provided with.

Please always view the files before writing to them, to make sure you are writing to the correct files.
When writing a test, make the filename start with the prefix 'test_'.

Provide the minimal code necessary to achieve the task conditioned on the existing generated code---including changing the existing generated code.

You cannot visualize any graphical output. You exist within a Actor Model machine, and when you list out steps, each step will be taken by a new separate sub-ChatGPT model. When you list out a sub-task steps, you can optionally specify the sub-task validation to check that it has been completed successfully.

You cannot use any databases as none are setup in the local environment, instead mock a database with an in memory dictionary to store data. No data saved to disk will persist between steps or write operations.

You will get instructions for code to write.
First lay out the names of the core classes, functions, methods that will be necessary, As well as a quick comment on their purpose.
Do not comment on what every file does. Please note that the code should be fully functional. No placeholders.

You will start with the "entrypoint" file, then go to the ones that are imported by that file, and so on.
Please note that the code should be fully functional. No placeholders.

Follow a language and framework appropriate best practice file naming convention.
Make sure that files contain all imports, types etc.  The code should be fully functional. Make sure that code in different files are compatible with each other.
When writing code if you are unsure, write a plausible implementation.
Include module dependency or package manager dependency definition file.

Useful to know:

For Python, you always create an appropriate requirements.txt file.
Always add a comment briefly describing the purpose of the function definition.
Add comments explaining very complex bits of logic.
Always follow the best practices for the requested languages for folder/file structure and how to package the project.
You can use any package and any other packages you wish to install.
You cannot use any databases as none are setup in the local environment, instead mock a database with an in memory dictionary to store data. No data saved to disk will persis between steps or write operations.
When writing a test, make the filename start with the prefix 'test_'.
                                       
Python toolbelt preferences:
- pytest
- dataclasses
- flask

Objective:```
**Global Chat Service (GCS)**

**Overview**:  
A real-time online chat application allowing users to send text messages, images, and create group chats.

**Functional Requirements to implement**:

User Registration and Authentication:
- [ ] 1.1. Sign up using email.
- [ ] 1.2. Forgotten password recovery.

User Profile:
- [ ] 2.1. Allow users to set profile pictures and status messages.
- [ ] 2.2. Privacy settings for who can see user details or last seen status.

Contact Management:
- [ ] 3.1. Block/unblock contacts.
- [ ] 3.2. Create, edit, and manage groups.

Messaging:
- [ ] 4.1. Send and receive real-time text messages.
- [ ] 4.2. Message read receipts (blue ticks or equivalent).
- [ ] 4.3. End-to-end encryption for security.
- [ ] 4.4. Image sharing.
- [ ] 4.5. Emojis, GIFs, and stickers support.

Group Chats:
- [ ] 5.1. Create group chats with a name and picture.
- [ ] 5.2. Add or remove participants.
- [ ] 5.3. Admin roles and permissions.

Status/Story Feature:
- [ ] 6.1. Allow users to post image statuses visible for a limited time.
- [ ] 6.2. Control who can see the status.

Web Application:
- [ ] 7.1. Web-based version accessible from browsers.

Connectivity and Offline Mode:
- [ ] 8.1. Message queuing for when the user is offline; messages are sent once connectivity is restored.
- [ ] 8.2. Display online/offline status.
```

Understand the problem, by creating an extremely detailed step-by-step plan, where each step is long (multiple sentences) and in total includes every single feature requirement specified above, feel free to copy directly from it. Use no more than 10 steps in the plan. Create additional tests, checks and evaluation at each step when applicable to help make an excellent code implementation, where all the code is fully functional. Use best software design practices, and you can output large amounts of code at once. Please include a last sentence to create and run tests when implementing or writing code in that same step. You will receive no human input at any stage, so you cannot use a human to test. Only create a detailed plan to begin with, which includes designing and running tests to check that they all pass. Please be sure to include all of the specified feature requirements in the following plan.
